File.Title: The Spinothalamic System of the Rat. I. Locations of Cells of Origin

Abstract.S: Horseradish peroxidase retrograde transport has been used to locate neurons of the rat spinal cord and lower medulla that project to the thalamus, Eight groups of spinothalamic cells are identified, some of which are anatomically continuous with thalamically projecting groups in the lower medulla.
Most of the groups are seen only at the highest cervical levels, and several of them have not been previously recognised as spinothalamic relays.

They are marginal layer (M), ventral border of the substantia gelatinosa (SGu), neck of the dorsal horn (N), lateral cervical nucleus (LO, ventromedial portion of the dorsal horn (DHum), intermediate gray zone (ZGZ), dorsal portion of the ventral horn (VHd, and ventral portion of the ventral horn (VHu).
Most of the cell bodies are contralateral to their thalamic terminations; only the VHd group is ipsilateral.
The major finding conflicts with traditional concepts of the spinothalamic system, and concerns the rostrocaudal distribution of the cells of origin.
With the sole exception of the DHum group, the great majority of the thalamically projecting neurons of the rat are confined to the most rostra1 spinal levels (medulldcord junction through C4).
BeIow C4, most of the spinothalamic cells are concentrated in a single DHum group between levels T9 and L4, probably concerned with hindlimb proprioception.
The spinothalamic groups at high cervical levels may be relays for information ascending from lower regions.
This might help to explain why, in man, surgical destruction of fibres crossing the midline in a single high cervical segment can cause a loss of pain sensation over most of the body.

Introduction.S: The concept of the spinothalamic tract is 100 years old, but still presents important puzzles.
Surprisingly, perhaps, it is still not clear precisely which cells in the spinal cord project directly to the thalamus, or what their functions are.

According to the classical view, cells projecting directly to the somatosensory thalamus are present throughout the length of the spinal cord, with their somata in the contralateral gray matter and their axons crossing the midline to ascend in the anterolateral quadrant; and these neurons play an essential part in pain and temperature transmission (e.g., Edinger, 1889, '11; Mott, 1892, 1895; Spiller, '05; May, '06; Foerster and Gagel, '31; Le Gros Clark, '36; Kuru, '49; Morin et al., '51; Smith, '76; reviewed by Willis and Coggeshall, '78).
Parts of the classical view, which was based largely on observations of sensory deficits and patterns of neuronal degeneration resulting from spinal cord lesions, have always been open to question.

From the beginning, it was clear that the vast majority of ascending axons in the spinal cord did not reach as far as the thalamus, but ended propriospinally or in the bulbar brainstem (e.g., May, '06, for early review).

In particular, many of the fibres in the anterolateral quadrant, quite possibly including those concerned with pain and temperature, were reported to end in the brainstem reticular formation (e.g., May, '06; Kuru, '49; Morin et al., '51; Bowsher, '57; Nauta and Kuypers, '58; Anderson and Berry, '59; Mehler et al., '60; Mehler, '62; Breazile and Kitchell, '68; Bowsher and Westman, '70; Schroeder and Jane, '71; Kerr and Lippman, '74; Kerr, '75b; reviewed by Willis and Coggeshall, '78).
The information gleaned so far by these methods, while more precise than the older findings, is nevertheless incomplete in some important respects.

With the electrophysiological approach, it is impossible to be sure that one has a full or unbiased sampling of the spinothalamic population, and it is difficult to locate sites of origin and termination accurately.

HRP studies using large injections to fill the thalamus are liable to suffer from spread of HRP to adjacent regions, especially brainstem, leading to the labelling of cells that do not in fact project to the thalamus.

For reasons only partly to do with these technical problems, we have still only fragmentary information about the detailed topography of the spinothalamic projection-that is, about the differences between the various regions of the somatosensory thalamus as to the sources of their spinal input (Carstens and Trevino, '78a; Willis et al., '79; Giesler et al., '79a, '81a,b; Granum, '83; Peschanski et al., '83; Kevetter and Willis, '83, '84; Menetrey et al., '84b; Peschanski and Besson, '84).

Furthermore, the current picture of the distribution of spinothalamic cells along the length of the spinal cord is incomplete; most of the previous studies have foccussed attention on a few selected levels-typically high cervical, cervical enlargement, and/or lumbar enlargement-instead of systematically examining the whole rostrocaudal extent.
The present paper describes experiments using small localised injections of HRP into the somatosensory regions of the thalamus of the rat.
The aim at the outset was to discover the precise locations of the cells of origin of the spinothalamic projection.
It was decided to plot the rostrocaudal distribution of the spinothalamic cells very fully, saving and examining every section of the spinal cord from the medulla down to the coccyx.
As a first step in the analysis of the data, the results from all the thalamic injections were superimposed so as to display the total population of cells projecting to the thalamus.

These composite data, with which the present paper is chiefly concerned, reveal some interesting and unexpected features of the distribution of spinothalamic cells, especially along the rostrocaudal axis.

It appears that relatively few cells project directly to the thalamus from the lower levels of the spinal cord, but large numbers do so from the high cervical levels, where they are arranged in eight distinct groups.
By analogy with known groups in the brainstem, the high cervical groups may perhaps be relays for somatosensory information ascending from the lower part of the spinal cosd.

If one may extrapolate from rat to man, this may help to explain some remarkable clinical observations, in which a small lesion of the commissural fibres at a high cervical level abolished pain sensation over most of the body (Hitchcock, '70, '74; Pap0 and Luongo, '76; Schvarcz, '77, '78; Cook et al., '84).

Methods.S: METHODS
HRP injections
Adult Wistar albino rats of 270-320-g body weight were used.
Following initial ether anaesthesia, the animals were placed in a stereotaxic head holder and anaesthesia was maintained with an inhaled COz/O&alothane mixture.

Injections were made (through small holes drilled in the skull) via a 30-gauge needle held in a micromanipulator and connected via polythene tubing to a 1.00-pl Hamilton syringe, the dead space in the hydraulic system being filled with silicone fluid.

Thalamic injections of 30% HRP (Boehringer lyophilised grade I, in sterile water) were made in 16 rats, in the following manner: (1) Fourteen rats received single injections into specific thalamic targets. (2) One rat received two injections across the anterior zone of transition (anterior ventrobasal/posterior ventrolateral area) on one side. (3) One rat received eight separate injections that were intended to cover the somatosensory thalamus, but in the event lay partly outside it, in anterior thalamic regions that probably do not receive any spinal input.
The precise sites of injection and the extent of diffusion of the HRP were determined at the end of the experiment by analysis of the sectioned tissue.
The intended volume of HRP administered was between 0.02 and 0.06 pl per injection and was given over a period of 20-30 minutes, by means of a motorized apparatus (B.
Braun, Melsungen) to drive the plunger of the Hamilton syringe slowly.
After each injection, the needle was left in situ for 5-10 minutes and then slowly retracted.
Processing and histochemistry

Following the HRP injections, the animals were allowed to survive for 48 hours, and were then reanaesthetised with ether and killed by transcardiac perfusion with 200 ml of 0.9% saline, followed by 200 ml of 1% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.3), followed finally by 500 ml of 4% glutaraldehyde in the same buffer.
The brainstem and spinal cord were dissected out immediately after perfusion and immersed in the weaker fixative.
Transverse 60-pm-thick serial sections were cut on a freezing microtome, from the level of the anterior commissure through the entire length of the brainstem and spinal cord.
There were about 2,000 sections in the complete serial set for each animal; with minor exceptions, all of them were saved and processed.
(Some sections of rats R90 and R91 between T4 and T10 were lost, as were the sacrococcygeal regions of rats R61, R62, R64, and R90.)
The sections were collected in phosphate buffer and reacted for HRP using the o-dianisidine method (slightly modified from Colman et al., '76) at room temperature.
The serial sections were then mounted alternately on two sets of gelatinized slides: one set was counterstained with thionin and one was left unstained.
Analysis of material

From the brains of a separate set of control animals, thionin-stained sections were prepared and photographed and a series of 85 standard diagrams of successive levels of the thalamus, brainstem, and spinal cord were made; the region from the medulldcord junction down to the coccyx was spanned by a series of 26 of the atlas diagrams (see Fig. lD, 3C,D).
On these diagrams, the extent of the thalamic injection site in each animal was mapped, as well as all HRP-labelled cells throughout the lower medulla and spinal cord.

Faintly labelled cells were more easily visible in the uncounterstained series of sections, and they could be localised accurately by darkfield illumination (which helps to clarify cytoarchitectural boundaries) and comparison with the paired section in the counterstained series.

Each labelled cell observed was recorded as a single dot in the appropriate position relative to standard landmarks on the atlas diagram for the appropriate level of the spinal cord this was done for each animal separately.
Figure 1 illustrates the complete data recorded in this way from a single animal (R104).
To get quantitative data, the dots were then counted in each atlas diagram for each animal.
In a few specimens, the concentration of labeled cells in certain regions was so high that dots on the record diagram overlapped.
In these cases, the counts represent estimates rather than exact figures.

As a check on the magnitude of the error from this cause, the counts for the specimen with the largest number of labelled cells-R90-were repeated by an exact method, in which the labelled cells were recorded tissue section by tissue section, as well as atlas level by atlas level.
The total counts obtained by the two methods were, respectively, 975 and 941-a negligible discrepancy.
A further slight systematic error in the counts may result from double counting of cells split by the microtome knife into two parts on adjacent sections.

No attempt was made to apply the usual Abercrombie ( 46) correction for this, since the correction factor depends on the average cell diameter as measured perpendicular to the plane of section, which, for non-spherical cells such as neurons, cannot be deduced from the dimensions seen in the plane of section.

A rough estimate of the magnitude of the correction factor can, however, be made: for a section thickness of 60pm, the counts should be scaled down ~ 0 . 8 for 6 neurons with an average diameter of lOpm, and scaled down x0.67 for a diameter of 30pm.
These diameters roughly encompass the range of sizes encountered when one compares the different groups of labelled neurons identified in this study.
Thus the ratios of the counts of neurons in the different groups are not likely to be distorted by a factor of more than 0.8610.67, i.e., 1.28.

In fact, the error from double counting is probably even less than this, since profiles obviously identifiable as fragments of cells whose main bodies lay in adjacent sections were not included in the counts.

Results.S: RESULTS
The distribution of thalamic injection sites is shown graphically in Figure 2.
It can be seen that the injection sites are distributed widely throughout the somatosensory thalamus , although there is a larger concentration of injections in some regions than in others .

Thus , when all the retrograde tracing results are considered together , they should provide a reasonably complete picture of the population of cells projecting to the somatosensory thalamus , even though the picture may give somewhat exaggerated weight to those populations of cells that project to the more densely sampled regions of thalamus ( see also the Discussion below ) .

In the account that follows , all cells projecting from the spinal cord to the thalamus will be counted as belonging to the spinothalamic system , including those of the lateral cervical nucleus ( LCN ) and the small spinal extensions of the gracile and cuneate nuclei ( GN and CUM ) .
The term spinothalamic system in this paper, therefore, will denote a broader class of cells than those of the traditional spinothalamic tract.
Eight spinothalamic cell groups can be distinguished

To obtain a picture of the total population of spinothalamic cells seen in this study, the data from all the separate HRP experiments were superimposed on a single set of composite diagrams (Fig. 3A-C).

Figure 4 reproduces the cervical levels of Figure 3C ( but with all cells plotted on the same side of the cord ) and depicts schematically on cross sections of the spinal cord the anatomical boundaries of the spinothalamic groups that can be identified in this rostra1 region .
Figure 5 shows a graph of the distribution of spinothalamic cells along the rostrocaudal axis.

It can be seen from these figures that the population of cells projecting from the spinal cord to the thalamus consists of a number of distinct groups , and that there are dramatic differences in the distribution of labelled cells between different levels of the spinal cord .

While the spinothalamic cells fall into eight groups with respect to their location in the transverse plane , none of these eight groups is present at every cord level : all are distinct at high cervical levels , but only the ventromedial dorsal horn group , DHum , and to a much smaller extent the marginal group , M , are clearly represented in lower spinal cord segments ( Fig . 3C ) .
Apart from the DHvm group , the labelled neurons in the lower spinal cord are few in number and diffusely scattered : it is difficult to assign them to specific groups .

A still larger family of thalamically projecting nuclei are found in the brainstem proper ( see below ) , and the eight groups of spinothalamic cells clustered in high cervical segments may be the most caudal members of this constellation .
Indeed , at the highest cervical levels , the spinal extensions of the medullary gracile and cuneate nuclei ( GN and CUM ) are also evident , in addition to the eight groups to be described below .
Of the eight groups , seven are found on the side of the spinal cord contralateral to the thalamis HRP injections , and only one , in the dorsal portion of the ventral horn , VHd , is ipsilateral .
Five of the eight groups are laminar in arrangement and roughly parallel to the superficial border of the dorsal horn , occupying regions from the marginal layer to the ventral horn .
In addition, there are three groups that are nuclear rather than laminar in transverse outline.

Because an exact assignment of labelled neurons to Rexed ( 52, 54 ) laminae often cannot be made with certainty , and the laminae formed by thalamically projecting cells do not correspond exactly with Rexed laminae , the Rexed terminology will for the most part be avoided in this report .

It is , however , convenient for general orientation , as follows : The marginal group , M , lies in lamina I ; the group at the ventral border of the substantia gelatinosa , SGu , lies at the junction between laminae 11 and 111 ; the group in the neck of the dorsal horn , N , is in lamina IV and the most superficial part of lamina V ; the lateral cervical nucleus , LCN , is in the dorsolateral part of the lateral white fasciculus ; the group in the ventromedial part of the dorsal horn , DHum , is in the most medial part of lamina VI ; and the smaller and more laterally placed group in the intermediate gray zone , IGZ , lies in dorsal lamina VII ( and perhaps includes the most ventral part of lamina VI ) .

The two groups found in the ventral horn are partially overlapping : the more dorsal one , VHd , lies diagonally across the middle of lamina VII ; and the more ventral group , VHu , is in the deeper part of lamina VII and ( in the upper cervical cord ) in the upper parts of lamina VIII .

Descriptions of the eight spinothalamic groups , shown in Figures 3C and 4, and short statements regarding their relationship to the medullothalamic groups seen in the lower brainstem , follow : Marginal group ( MI .

This group of labelled cells lies in the most superficial lamina of the dorsal horn , capping the substantia gelatinosa , and is continuous rostrally with a similarly placed labelled subdivision of the nucleus of the trigeminal spinal tract pars caudalis ( NTSTc ; see below ) .
Labelling is most common at the medullaryicord junction and in the first and second cervical segments .
Cells are often clustered medially near the entry point of the dorsal roots.
A second concentration is clustered near the apex of the dorsal horn , in C6 - T4, but in the remainder of the spinal cord labelled marginal cells are extremely rare .
Occasionally cells are seen embedded in the white matter , quite close to the pial surface .
Many, though not all, labelled M cells have the classic Waldeyer fusiform profile, with the long axis usually lying parallel to the gelatinosa surface.
About 94% of labelled cells in this lamina are contralateral to the injection site ; about 6% are ipsilateral .
Ventral border of the substantia gelatinosa (SGv).

This laminar group of labelled cells is found just ventral to the hyaline substantia gelatinosa and is continuous with a similar group within the nucleus of the trigeminal spinal tract , pars caudalis , NTSTc .
In the cord , SGv neurons are prominent only at the most rostra1 two segments , and are extremely rare in the remaining cord levels .
(The bulk of the SGv group lies in fact in the medulla.)

Even in Cl - C2, labelled cells belonging to this group are not common , but when present , they are often in close proximity to ( and just across the substantia gelatinosa from ) a labelled M neuron .
With very rare exceptions , SGv cells are contralateral .
Neck of the dorsal horn ( N ) .
This group of labelled cells stretches across most of the neck of the dorsal horn, roughly parallel to the M and SGv groups described above.
Labelled N cells are most frequent from the medulldcord junction to the fourth cervical segment , but are very occasionally seen throughout the rest of the spinal cord .
Cells are frequently grouped in the lateral half of the lamina , and the boundary of this group with the lateral cervical nucleus ( LCN ) is sometimes indistinct .
The cells are almost all contralateral .
These three groups - M , SGU , and possibly N - are all anatomically continuous with labelled subdivisions of the nucleus of the trigeminal spinal tract , pars caudalis , NTSTc .
Together they account for approximately 16% of the total number of spinothalamic cells seen in these experiments.
This is a well - known group of labelled cells in the dorsal part of the lateral white matter .

At high cervical levels this group is termed the lateral cervical nucleus ( LCN ) ; at lower levels it has been termed variously the interstitial nucleus of the lateral fasciculus ( ZNLF ) , the nucleus of the dorsolateral fasciculus ( NDLF ) , or the lateral spinal nucleus ( LSN ) .

The labelled neurons are most numerous at the most rostra1 levels - i . e . , in the LCN proper - but a very sparse population of thalamically projecting ZNLF neurons extends in fact throughout the full length of the cord .
Many of the labelled cells are in the peripheral extreme of the white matter , close to the pial surface ( Fig . 3C ) .
Other cells are more medial , and the LCN merges with the lateral part of the N lamina described above .
Most neurons of LCN (and ZNLF) are small to moderate, rounded or ovoid, averaging approximately 30 pm in their longest diameter.
Larger labelled neurons tend to lie more laterally and smaller ones lie more medially , where the nucleus merges with the neck of the dorsal horn .
In these experiments, this entire LCNIINLF system accounts for about 13% of the total number of labelled cells seen.
More than 90% of the labelled LCN cells were contralateral to the injection .
Ventmmedial portion of the dorsal horn (DHvm).
This group of labelled cells lies in the ventromedial extreme of the dorsal horn .
It is bordered medially by the central gray area, with whose dorsolateral part it may merge, and dorsally by the dorsal fasciculus.
Dorsolaterally it overlaps the intermediate basilar nucleus ( ZBN ) .
Ventrolaterally it becomes continuous with the intermediate gray zone (ZGZ).

As with all of the spinothalamic groups , DHvm is distinct at high cervical levels , but in striking contrast to all other groups it is also prominent at lower thoracic and upper lumbar levels , from T9 to L4.
At lower cord levels , the group of labelled DHvm cells extends ventromedially well into the central gray area : it is possible that this extension could represent a separate group .
Labelled DHvm neurons are usually moderate in size ( 30 - 40 pm ) , and although they are not strictly fusiform , their dendrites are often aligned dorsolaterally - ventromedially .
This profile is most common in cells nearest the junction between the spinal gray and the dorsal fasciculus.

In the very highest cervical segments occasional thalamically projecting DHvm neurons are seen within the intermediate basilar nucleus ( ZBN ; the convexity on the medial border of the dorsal horn - compare Giesler et al . , ' 79a ) .
More typically , the labelled cells cluster just ventromedially to ZBN .
The more dorsolateral portion of IBN, by contrast, is populated by cells that appear to represent the caudalmost limits of the medial cuneate nucleus (CUM, see Fig. 3C).
At least 90% of labelled DHvm cells are contralateral to the injection site : one or two ipsilateral cells are present , however , even in thoracic and lumbar cord .
Intermediate gray zone ( IGZ ) .
This group of cells lies in the transition zone between dorsal and ventral horns .
It is clearly seen from the medulldcord junction down to lower C3 or upper C4, and is most prominent in C1 and C2.
Occasional cells are seen in this lamina in the thoracic and lumbar cord .
Labelled cells of IGZ vary greatly in size and shape.

The border between this zone and DHvm is not clear at any level, but as the DHvm and ZGZ groups may label independently after separate injections (Granum, in preparation; also Menetrey et al., '84b), the two regions are considered separately.
The great majority of labelled cells are contralateral to the injection site .
Dorsal portion of the ventral horn (VHd).
This group of HRP - filled cells lies diagonally across the upper part of the ventral horn , ventral and slightly caudal to IGZ , but ipsilateral to the site of injection .
Labelled cells are most numerous in the lateral region , and some cells spill over the graylwhite boundary into the lateral funiculus .
The group is present from the medulldcord junction to the fifth cervical segment and is most prominent in C1 - C3.
Rare members of the group are seen as far caudally as lower thoracic and upper lumbar segments .
VHd is parallel to the other four spinothalamic laminae (M, SGv, N, and IGZ), but it differs from all the other spinothalamic groups in that it is ipsilateral to the site of injection.
The sizes and shapes of spinothalamic cells in this lamina vary greatly from narrow fusiform to large multipolar: some of the latter may be as large as the motor neurons of the ventral horn.
Ventral part of the ventral horn (VHu).
Labelled cells in this group are in the deepest part of the ventral horn .
The lateral portions of VHv partly overlap the region covered Fig. 5.
Graph of the total number of spinothalamic cells ( except R59 for which the lower cord segments were not by VHd .
The VHu group is seen clearly from the medulla/ cord junction to the fourth cervical segment and is most prominent in Cl-C3.
Rare spinothalamic cells are seen deep in the ventral horn as far caudally as lower thoracic and upper lumbar segments .
However , as with every other group except DHurn , labelled VHu cells are not only far less common in the lower cord but are more randomly arranged .

Labelled neurons in this group are usually moderately large multipolar cells , whose axons may sometimes be seen in the same section as the soma , following a steep dorsomedial trajectory - possibly toward the anterior white commissure .
Most cells are contralateral to the site of injection : occasional ipsilateral members are seen at upper cervical levels , and very rarely in lower thoracic segments .
The set of spinothalamic groups is continuous with a set of medullothalamic groups

The division between brainstem and spinal cord is not anatomically abrupt , and some of the spinothalamic groups appear to be continuous across the cordlmedulla junction with lower brainstem nuclei ( see Fig . 3B , C ) .

Numerous groups of labelled neurons were seen in the lower medulla , some of which ( e . g . , the trigeminal and dorsal column nuclei ) are well - known sources of thalamic afTerents ( Fig . 3A , B ) .
Brief mention will be made here regarding only those medullothalamic groups that are particularly relevant to the spinothalamic study.
Dorsolateral reticular formation ( DLRF ) ( nucleus Z ? ) .
It is possible that this group represents the rodent counterpart of the feline nucleus Z (Brodal and Pompeiano, '57).
The labelled cells lie just medial to the inferior cerebellar peduncle in the dorsal and lateral regions of the medullary gray .
The group is already present at the most rostral level examined ( level 80 - 81 of Pellegrino et al . , ' 79 ; level 45 in Fig . 3A ) and may extend more rostrally still .

At this level it occupies the territory normally ascribed to the spinal vestibular nucleus , but more caudally the labelled population shifts ventral to the spinal vestibular nucleus , ending just rostral to the medial cuneate nucleus , or possibly shifting more ventrally to become continuous with the dorsomedial border of the nucleus of the trigeminal spinal tract .
More than 90% of the cells in this nucleus are contralateral to the injection site.
Ventrolateral reticular formation ( VLRF ) .
This group may be what is termed by others the lateral reticular formation, LRF .
It is in the most ventral region of the lower medulla , lateral to the pyramidal tract and olive .

From level 46 to level 49 ( Fig . 3A ) the labelled cells form a relatively compact group ; from level 50 to level 60 ( Fig . 3A , B , the medulldcord junction ) , it continues as a sparse population , and finally appears to be continuous into the spinal cord with a second concentration of ventrally placed cells - the group in the ventral part of the spinal ventral horn, VHu .
About 85 - 90% of these labelled cells are contralateral to the injection .
Nucleus of the trigeminal spinal tract ( NTST ) .
This nucleus shows a dense concentration of labelled perikarya , which extends caudally to become continuous with the dorsal laminae of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord ( Fig . 3AC ) .

The subdivisions of the nucleus show different degrees of labelling : subnucleus oralis fNTSTo ) shows sparse labelling at its rostra1 end , increasing caudally ; subnucleus interpolaris ( NTSTi ) is extremely densely labelled ; and subnucleus caudalis ( NTSTc ) shows moderate to light labelling .
Within NTSTc, lamination of labelled cells becomes apparent, and a number of subgroups can be defined that are continuous through the medulldcord junction with HRPlabelled dorsal horn laminae.

For instance , labelled cells in the marginal layer capping the medullary substantia gelatinosa form a group that is continuous caudally with the spinal M group ; and cells within NTSTc that are just ventral to the medullary substantia gelatinosa compose a group that is continuous with the spinal SGU group .
Other labelled cells within NTSTc are in a group that continues into the neck group ( N ) of the dorsal horn .
Gracile nucleus ( GN ) .
Labelled cells are present throughout this nucleus , extending down through the medulldcord junction into upper cervical levels .
Almost all the labelled neurons are contralateral .
Lateral cuneate nucleus ( CUL ) .

Although a number of cells are seen that appear to be within the boundaries of CUL , the impression from the plotted data is that these really represent an overflow population of cells from GN or CUM ( see Fig . 3B , C ) .
Medial cuneate nucleus ( CUM ) .
This nucleus also contains labelled cells throughout its length in the medulla , and labelling extends through the medulldcord junction to the upper cervical segments .
As in GN and NTST , more than 98% of the labelled cells are contralateral .
The thalamically projecting populations in the trigeminal and dorsal column nuclei are more strictly contralateral than any others within the medulla and spinal cord .
The number of neurons projecting to thalamus in Cl - C4 is much greater than the number projecting to thalamus in the whole of the rest of the spinal cord

From Table 1, summarising the counts of labelled cells in different regions , it can be seen that in every individual animal analysed , the number of labelled cells projecting to the thalamus from the four uppermost spinal segments , from the medulldcord junction through C4, is greater than the number projecting from the whole of the lower part of the spinal cord , consisting of the 27 segments from C5 down to the coccyx .
The maximum proportion of labelled cells in the lower part of the cord was seen in rat R64, and amounted to only 44% of the total , or 191 cells out of 439.

If one adds together the counts for all the specimens analysed , one finds that the number for the lower part of the cord amounts to only 25% of the total ( or 28% if we exclude the cells of the gracile and cuneate nuclei from the total ) .
Admittedly, combining the data in this fashion may introduce some distortion of the figures since the various injection sites do not represent a uniform sampling of the thalamus.

Nevertheless , the full set of specimens does represent a sampling of practically every region of the somatosensory thalamus , and the finding for each individual animal is qualitatively similar , whether one looks at , for example , rat R90 ( large injection into centre of thalamus and spanning practically the whole thalamus ) , R99 ( injection into posteromedial pole ) , or R106 ( injection into anterior zone of transition , i . e . , anterolateral pole ) ; these three specimens have , respectively , 11% , 21% , and 34% of their labelled neurons in the lower part of the spinal cord .
Most of the labelled neurons in the lower part of the spinal cord lie in a single group ( DHum ) in the ventromedial part of the dorsal horn , and are confined to segments T9 - L4

Focussing on the relatively small proportion of spinothalamic neurons detected in the lower part of the spinal cord , from C5 down to the coccyx , one finds that the great majority of these are concentrated in a single group in the ventromedial part of the dorsal horn , DHum .

Aggregating the counts from all the specimens, as before, we find that 68% of the total c5-co population lie in DHvm, and that 90% of those DHum cells are concentrated in just eight segments, from T9 to L4.
Again, these figures may be somewhat distorted by uneven sampling of the thalamus, but a qualitatively similar phenomenon is seen in practically every animal.

The largest number of non - DHum cells detected in any single animal in the whole of the lower part of the cord was 87 out of a total c5 - co population of 172 ( in R107 ) , while the largest number of DHum cells detected in any single animal in the lower part of the cord was 168, out of a total c5 - co population of 191 ( in R64 ) .
In no specimen were more than 21 DHum cells detected in the lower part of the cord outside the segments T9 - L4.
It should be noted that besides the DHvm group in segments T9 - L4, there is a large DHvm group in the upper part of the cord , in C4 and above .

The total number of DHvm cells amounts to 35% of the total spinothalamic population, as judged from the composite data, and with the same provisos as before as to possible bias due to nonuniform sampling of the thalamus.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

The chief observation to emerge from these experiments is that in the rat the large majority of all monosynaptic projections from the spinal cord to the thalamus are made by neurons whose cell bodies are in the most rostral four segments of the cervical cord, and that the relatively small number of cells projecting to the thalamus from the lower part of the cord lie mostly in a single highly localised group apparently associated with the hindlimbs.

This point about the craniocaudal distribution of spinothalamic cells will be discussed last, after considering three other observationsnamely, that spinothalamic cells are arranged in eight discrete groups, or nuclei; that most spinothalamic cells are contralateral to the thalamus on which they project, with one clearly ipsilateral group; and that the spinothalamic projections from individual groups are widespread but not uniform in distribution.
Spinothalamic cells are arranged into several distinct groups, or nuclei

The finding of so large a number as eight anatomically distinct groups of cells projecting from spinal cord to thalamus (Figs. 3C, 4) was unexpected, and suggests that there may be a similar diversity of functionally distinct spinothalamic pathways.

The spinothalamic neurons are not confined to the dorsal horn (which is the traditional sensory domain of the spinal cord): as previous studies (reviewed below) have also shown, some of them are located in deep gray areas and even in the very deepest part of the ventral horn.
The relatively discrete groups into which thalamically projecting cells are arranged for the most part do not fit easily into Rexed's ('52, '54) laminar classification.

And particularly since results here indicate that upper cervical segments contain groups not present at other levels in the cord, it seems inappropriate to use a classification designed as a uniform description for the entire spinal cord.

By the same token, in speculating about the functions of the individual groups described here, one must be cautious: it would be rash to assume, for example, that all the lamina I cells in the marginal layer of Cl-C4 have the same functional properties as the lamina I cells of the lumbar cord.
This is an important point, since electrophysiological studies have tended to concentrate on the lower levels of the spinal cord, which are more easily accessible.
A detailed discussion of the likely functions of the individual groups will be presented in another paper, in connection with their differential projections to the various regions of the thalamus.
There are, however, some general comments to be made here on the relations between the present and previous findings.
Findings of others

The major previous studies of the distribution of spinothalamic and trigeminothalamic cells in the rat have been those of Dilly et al. ('681, Giesler et al. ('76, '79a), Fukushima and Kerr ('79), Kevetter and Willis ('831, and Men& trey et al. ('84b).
These studies describe the pattern seen in the transverse plane at selected levels.
The present work is, however, the first to record systematically the distribution throughout the whole length of the spinal cord.

The previous findings as to the distribution of spinothalamic cells in the transverse plane, as seen at rostral levels, are basically in accord with the present results: no groups of cells were seen in regions where the present study saw none, nor does the present study find spinothalamic cells where none were found before.

However, the arrangement of the spinothalamic cells into eight relatively discrete groups, clear when the data from many animals are superimposed, as here, is not generally apparent in the previous studies.

While some groups, such as LEN, VHd, and (in certain figures) M and DHum, were obvious, others, more sparsely populated, were not resolved as separate, but appeared merged into a single diffuse distribution.
Moreover, the previous studies offer a somewhat different view of the rostrocaudal distribution of the spinothalamic cells (see below).

Much work has been done on the laminar arrangement of spinothalamic neurons, as seen in transverse sections, in other species besides the rat (cat: Carstens and Trevino, '78a,b; Dilly et al., '68; Trevino, '76; Trevino and Carstens, '75a,b; monkey: Albe-Fessard et al., '75; Giesler et al., '81b; Levante et al., '73; Trevino, '76; Trevino and Carstens, '75a,b; Willis et al., '78, '79).

The most comprehensive studies-those of Trevino and Carstens ('75a,b) on cat and monkey, of Carstens and Trevino ('78a) on cat, and of Willis et al. ('79) on the monkey-show many similarities with the present results.

Moreover, if, instead of following the Rexed laminar classifications used by these authors, comparison is made between original figures, it becomes clear that some of the apparent species differences are largely a matter of nomenclature.

All the groups seen here in the upper cervical segments of the spinal cord have counterparts in similar locations in the cat (see, for example, Carstens and Trevino, '78a), except that no distinct SGU group is apparent.

At upper cervical levels in the monkey, the groups reported here for the rat again have similar counterparts, except for SGu, DHum, and IGZ (see, for example, Trevino, '76; Trevino and Carstens, '75a,b).

At lumbar levels, the apparent species differences are more marked: in cat, as in rat, DHvm is the most prominent group; but more cells are also seen in the marginal zonehubstantia gelatinosa (M and possibly SGv) and the neck of the dorsal horn (N) (Trevino and Carstens, '75a,b; Willis et al., '79).

In the monkey there does not seem to be a DHvm group, but a possible counterpart is visible in a more diffuse and slightly more ventral group of spinothalamic cells in the dorsomedial part of the ventral horn.

The DHvm group is of special interest, since it is the only major spinothalamic group in the lower part of the cord of the rat, and also contains a major part of the spinothalamic population in the upper part of the cord.

Menetrey et al. ('84b) have shown that at lumbar levels it deals with information from the hindlimbs, and that its cells are driven by a combination of proprioceptive and cutaneous inputs in a manner that suggests a role in the monitoring or control of hindlimb movement.
Most spinothalamic cells are contralateral to the thalamus on which they project; one group in the dorsal part of the ventral horn, VHd, is ipsilateral

In agreement with previous accounts of the spinothalamic tract, and with traditional spinothalamic tract concepts, most of the spinothalamic cells seen in this study are contralateral to the thalamus on which they project.

Both clinical (e.g., French and Peyton, 48; Voris, 51; Nathan and Smith, 59; White and Sweet, 69) and experimental (e.g., Basbaum, 73; Albe-Fessard and Fessard, 75) observations have indicated, however, that there must also be ipsilateral (though not necessarily monosynaptic) cord-tothalamus routes for sensory information.
VHd is the only prominent ipsilateral group in the spinal cord (though there are several others in the medulla).

This group, which is largely confined to the high cervical levels, is evidently the same as the ipsilateral spinothalamic group identified by Trevino ( 76) in the monkey, and by Carstens and Trevino ( 78a,b) in the cat, and noted also by Giesler et al. ( 79a) in the rat.
The function of these ipsilateral cells remains something of a mystery.

Carstens and Trevino ( 78b) found that in the cat many of them were unresponsive to all the somatosensory stimuli that were tried, while others had enormous receptive fields, sometimes bilaterally symmetrical and extending over almost the entire body surface, and responded to a wide range of different types of cutaneous stimulation.

The account given by Giesler et al. ( 79a) conveys the impression that there is a bilaterally projecting group of celIs in the intermediate gray zone and ventral horn of the rat at high cervical levels; but the present findings indicate that there are three different groups, closely neighbouring but in distinct locations-IGZ projecting primarily contralaterally, VHd projecting primarily ipsilaterally, and VHu projecting primarily contralaterally.

It is easy to confirm that VHd and VHu only partially overlap by superimposing the composite diagram of Figure 3C on its mirror image (as is done in Fig. 4), thereby bringing the contralateral and ipsilateral populations together on the same side of the cord for comparison.

Although every thalamically projecting group seen in the present experiments projects primarily to just the thalamus of one side (usually contralateral, rarely ipsilateral), small numbers of nonconformist cells are also seen.
That is, in every group that projects to one thalamus, there are occasional cells projecting to the other thalamus.
Several of the medullary reticular formation groups have a significantly larger proportion of such cells, but as a rule in the spinal cord, such cells are few in number (less than 3%).
If there are any truly bilateral connections, they may be likely to be found among these nonconformist cells.
In fact, Kevetter and Willis ( 83) report, from double labelling experiments, that less than 2% of spinothalamic cells project bilaterally.

It is impossible to say at present whether the smaII numbers of cells projecting atypically in each group have important functions, or merely represent developmental anomalies or superfluous connections.
Spinothalamic projections are widespread yet nonuniform in distribution

The composite presentation obscures the conclusions that have to do with differential projections of individual spinal groups to the various thalamic targets (studied also by Giesler et al., 76, 79a).
To get that differential information, one must look at each experiment individually and compare the results of injecting HRP into different regions of the thalamus.

The general finding from the present experiments is that the different thalamic targets-the three somatosensory complexes, ventrobasal WB), posterolateral (LP), and intralaminar (1L)-do receive different proportions of their spinal input from the various spinal groups.
And yet, most of the spinal groups project quite widely throughout the somatosensory thalamus.
A short way of expressing this is to say that the thalamic projection of an individual group is widespread but differential, or widespread but not uniform.

Previous studies of the differential projections of spinothalamic cells in the rodent have concluded that the lateral thalamic areas receive most of their direct spinal input from the more superficial dorsal horn laminae, while the medial thalamus receives most of its spinal input from deeper laminae (Giesler et al., 76, 79a).
The present experiments led basically to the same conclusion, but only for the caudal half of the thalamus.
In the anterior portion, the picture is somewhat different.
The far anterior pole of the ventrobasal complex-the anterior zone of transition-receives most of its spinal input from DHum, and appears to receive none from M or SGU groups.
DHvm projects to other areas in the anterior and middle portions of the VB, LP, and IL complexes, but probably not to the far posterior poles of either VB or K.

The far posterior pole of VB receives most of its spinal input from M, SGu, N, and LCN and the far posteromedial pole of the somatosensory thalamus-the intralaminar parafascicular nucleus (IUPf)) and/or the overlying pretectal area-receives most of its spinal input from IGZ, VHd, and VHu.
Most of the details of differential projections will be presented in a future paper.

Just one aspect of the differential projections will be highlighted here: namely, that the anterior zone of the thalamus receives most of its spinal input from the group in the ventromedial portion of the dorsal horn, DHum; that is, from the only group that has a large representation at lower as well as higher levels of the spinal cord.
Thus the three animals with the most anterior thalamic injections-R106, R63, and R64-had, respectively, 63%, 64%, and 60% of their labelled spinal cells in DHum.
By comparison, the two animals with the most posterior injection sites-R99 and R105had, respectively, only 8% and 5% of their labelled spinal cells in DHum.
Injections placed halfway between these poles, such as the very large injection of R90, mostly give an intermediate figure-in the case of R90,25%.
The present results tally in an informative way with the findings of Lund and Webster ( 67).

Their degeneration study serves to reinforce the present finding that most spinothalamic cells lie in the most rostra1 part of the cord (see below); and the present study serves to explain a main conclusion of theirs, the significance of which was previously unclear: namely, the statement that most of the rodent spinothalamic tract ends in the anterior one-third of the somatosensory thalamus.
To find where within the rat thalamus the spinothalamic fibres projected, those authors hemisected the spinal cord and looked for the terminal degeneration in the thalamus.
They observed that a hemisection at almost any level of the spinal cord resulted in thalamic degeneration that was confined mainly to the most anterior part of the somatosensory thalamus.
It was only when they hemisected the cord at the very highest cervical levels that they found much degeneraton extending back through the rest of the somatosensory thalamus.

This is just what the present results would lead one to expect: hemisection anywhere below C3 or C4 should provoke terminal degeneration chiefly in the region of the thalamus where the projection from DHvm predominates, since this would be the only major projection that was severed; hemisection well above C3 might sever also the axons from all the other seven spinothalamic groups, and so should provoke widespread degeneration in thalamus.
Lund and Webster tentatively attributed the degeneration that was seen only after high cervical hemisection to involvement of fibres coming from the lateral cervical nucleus, LCN.
The present results show that LCN is only one of a family of high cervical spinothalamic groups that must contribute to the degeneration and have widespread projections in the somatosensory thalamus.

A chain of evidence points to anatomical and functional connections relating group Ia afferent signals from the periphery, through the DHvm group, to the anterior zone of transition in the ventrobasal complex, and to cortical area 3a.
Brown s morphological work ( 81) indicates that group Ia muscle spindle afferents have terminals in the vicinity of the DHum somata.
And Menetrey et al. ( 84b) show that DHvm cells receive both cutaneous and propriospinal input from the periphery.
The results reported here indicate that the DHvm group provides the major input (in terms of numbers of spinothalamic cells) to the anterior zone of transition of the ventrobasal complex.

This fits with other observations that group Ia muscle afferents relay in rostral VB in the cat (Andersson et al., 66), and input from deep tissues relays in rostral VB in the monkey (Poggio and Mountcastle, 63; Albe-Fessard, 67).

In the monkey at least, the most anterior portion of the ventrobasal complex (the so-called ventroposterolateral nucleus pars oralis, VPLo) has been shown by Jones and Powell ( 70) to provide the most intense input to cortical area 3a, which is the transitional area between sensory and motor cortex and receives, among other inputs, information from group I muscle afferents in the cat and baboon (Oscarsson and Rosen, 66; Landgren et al., 67; Landgren and Silfvenius, 69; Phillips et al., 71) and unspecified deep stimuli in the rhesus monkey (Powell and Mountcastle, 59; cited in Jones and Powell, 73).
The majority of spinothalamic cells are in the highest four cervical segments

Perhaps the most important finding of the present study is the observation that the large majority of spinothalamic cells in the rat are found in the very most rostral levels of the cord, rostral even to the cervical enlargement proper.

Moreover, the more caudal spinothalamic neurons (those below C4) lie mostly in a single group, DHvm, confined primarily to segments T9-L4, and are apparently involved in proprioceptive sensation in the hindlimbs (Menetrey et al., 84a).
Setting aside the DHvm group in segments T9L4, the largest number of spinothalamic neurons detected in the whole of the spinal cord below C4 in any single animal was 94 (in R107).
In terms of the aggregated data for all the animals, the cells in the 27 segments below C4 that do not belong to the DHvm group in T9-L4 add up to only 10% of the total spinothalamic population.

Even allowing for uneven representaton of different parts of the rat s body, it seems unlikely that so small a population of cells could play more than a minor part in relaying the sensations of pain and temperature from the whole of the body, from the neck down, or that they could contribute more than a tiny proportion of the tens of thousands of axons that constitute the anterolateral funiculus.

It seems that the traditional simple conception of the human spinothalamic tract, as presented in elementary textbooks, can scarcely be regarded as even an approximation to the truth for the rat; for according to this conception, the major spinothalamic projection, conveying pain and temperature information, should be made from cells distributed along the whole length of the spinal cord, with their somata close to the sites of entry of the associated primary afferents, and their axons in the anterolateral fasciculus contralateral to the primary afferents.

The present observations suggest that, in the rat at least, one must invoke other pathways, such as the well-established spinoreticulothalamic, not merely as a supplement to the traditional spinothalamic tract, but as a substitute for it.
Validity of the observations (technical considerations).
In view of the apparent conflict with tradition, and before pursuing this line of argument further, the present findings must be scrutinised with respect to two questions of experimental technique.
First, is the experimental method efficient for detecting caudally placed spinal neurons projecting to the thalamic injection sites?

The speed of retrograde axonal transport in mammals is of the order of 200 mm or more per day (Grafstein and Forman, go), so that the 48-hour survival time used in these experiments should certainly have been sufficient-long enough for transport of HRP over a distance of at least 400 mm, which is three or four times the distance from thalamus to coccyx.

In any case, although most of the spinothalamic cells that were detected lay at high cervical levels, a second major concentration (the DHvm group) was also seen regularly at lower thoracichpper lumbar levels.

This argues against the possibility that the relatively low numbers of labelled cells in the thoracic and lumbar segments might have been due to a technical artifact related to tissue processing or insufficient survival times.

Variation of the order in which the tissue was cut and processed (i.e., caudal to rostral vs. rostral to caudal) made no apparent difference in the craniocaudal distribution of labelled cells (personal observations).

Admittedly, it is conceivable that some parts of the spinothalamic population might be underrepresented in consequence of a feeble capacity for uptake of HRP from the injection site; but there is no reason to expect that this would affect the lower levels of the spinal cord more than the higher.
Thus, it is likely that the present findings are a fair reflection of the relative paucity of neurons at thoracic and lumbar levels projecting to the thalamic injection sites.
The second technical question is whether one can be sure that the injections adequately sampled the somatosensory thalamus.

The target areas were (1) the ventrobasal complex (VB); (2) the posterolateral complex (LP) (now usually called the posterior (PO) or posteromedial (POm) complex, although the terms are not exactly synonymous); and (3) the intralaminar complex (IL).
All of these areas were sampled in the present work, as shown by Figure 2 and the isometric diagram in Figure 1A.
But do these areas constitute the entire somatosensory thalamus?
The question is complicated by lack of consistency in the nomenclature of different authors.
This is particularly true concerning PO and/or POm, which is now widely recognised as a major thalamic sensory nucleus, but previously was not.

The terms posterior thalamic region, posterior nuclear complex, posterior nucleus, or posterior group (all abbreviated PO); and posteromedial nucleus, or medial division of the posterior group (both abbreviated POm), have been used by different authors in confusingly different senses (see Lund and Webster, 67; Mehler, 69; Jones and Burton, 74; Burton and Jones, 76; Boivie, 78).
Emmers ( 65) believes the rat PO homologue is actually within the lateral part of the ventrobasal complex.
Mehler ( 69) holds that it is probably caudal to the ventroposterolateral nucleus, but certainly consists of very few cells.
Lund and Webster ( 67) state that it appears to comprise the medial geniculate complex pars suprageniculata . . . and may include the nucleus posterior parabrachialis (but compare Mehler, 69).
Scheibel and Scheibel( 66) label as rodent PO a large area caudal to the ventrobasal complex and assert that this area receives a large amount of spinal input.

Thus, by some authors definition, the rat somatosensory thalamus will have been wholly sampled in the thalamic target areas injected in this study; and by other authors definitions, the most caudal part of the rat PO (or POm) may have been missed.
Slightly more widespread regions have been sampled by S.K.
Kemplay and K.E.

Webster (personal communication) in a later repetition of the experiments reported here, using animals that were given multiple HRP injections; by any author s definition, these covered all of PO (or POm) and yielded the same qualitative finding-namely, a relative paucity of spinothalamic cells in the lower cord.

Thus one can be reasonably confident that these procedures have indeed detected a representative sample of essentially all the cells projecting directly from the spinal cord to the somatosensory thalamus.

Hence one can probably trust the conclusion that only a minority of these spinothalamic neurons lie at thoracic or lumbar levels, and that of that minority, only a small proportion lie outside the DHvm group.
The findings of others.
If this picture is accurate, why has it not been reported before?
The reason seems to lie chiefly in the way the different rostrocaudal levels have been sampled.

Several of the previous studies of the distribution of spinothalamic cells in the rat focus only on the most rostral (Fukushima and Kerr, 79) or only on the lumbosacral (Kevetter and Willis 82; Menetrey et al., 84b) part of the spinal cord.
None of the previous HRP studies recorded the distribution of labelled cells in every section, throughout the entire length of the spinal cord, as has been done here.

Thus Kevetter and Willis ( 83) apparently examined only the upper cervical levels and the cervical and lumbar enlargements, while Giesler et al. ( 79a) show data only for spinal segments C1, C2, C7, T6, L3, and L6.
For the most part these earlier findings, though they convey at first sight a different emphasis, do not conflict with the present, more complete, data.
Just one of the animals illustrated by Giesler et al. ( 79a) shows a concentration of cells in the neck of the dorsal horn at lumbar levels, where they were rarely seen in the present study.

But this was an animal that had received six injections of HRP intended to fill the entire thalamus, and some of the HRP may have diffused beyond the boundaries of the thalamus, and in particular into brainstem areas known to receive afferents from the spinal cord, such as the zona incerta, pretectum, and superior colliculus.

Kevetter and Willis ( 83) also show a noticeable concentration of cells in the neck region at lumbar levels, but this may have a similar explanation, since the volume of tracer that they injected was ten times greater than in the present study.
It is striking that they found the neck region at lumbar levels to contain very large numbers of labelled cells when they injected their tracer into the medullary reticular formation.
Essentially similar comments apply to the published HRP studies of the distribution of spinothalamic cells in cat and monkey (cited above).

In these species, too, attention has generally been focussed on a few selected rostrocaudal levels-most often high cervical, cervical enlargement, andor lumbar enlargement-and, as for the rat, it appears that through spread of the tracer some of the cells classed as spinothalamic may have been spinoreticular.
It is possible that the true picture of the rostrocaudal distribution of spinothalamic cells may be roughly similar in rat, cat, and monkey.
Some evidence in regard to man will be considered below.
Implications.
The traditional simple conception of the spinothalamic tract was developed at the end of the last century, largely on the basis of two classes of observations, attested by many investigators.

First, when the anterolateral funiculus was severed, sensory deficits, especially but not exclusively with regard to pain and temperature, were seen caudal to the lesion and on the opposite side of the body; and second, after the same lesion, at least some anterograde degeneration was seen to extend up into the thalamus on the same side as the lesion (reviewed: May, 06; Willis and Coggeshall, 78).

Hence it was proposed that sensations of pain and temperature were carried by neurons whose axons crossed the spinal cord close to the site of entry of the primary afferents, and ran in the anterolateral funiculus to terminate in the thalamus.

But it was clear from the beginning that the observations did not force this conclusion: it could not be assumed that all the axons in the anterolateral funiculus ascend as far as the thalamus; nor could it be assumed that the axons that did ascend to the thalamus were the ones carrying pain and temperature sensations.

Indeed, degeneration studies (cited above, in the beginning of this paper) indicated that most spinal cord neurons with long ascending axons did not ascend as far as the thalamus, but appeared to end in the brainstem reticular formation.
Thus it could be argued that routes from the spinal cord to the thalamus might be mostly polysynaptic, via a chain of relays (e.g., Ranson, 43; Basbaum, 73).

And, interestingly, Rothmann ( 04- 05, cited in May, 06), during the debate at the turn of the century over whether any fibres reach from the spinal cord all the way to the thalamus, affirmed that although some did, it was possible that they did so only from the most rostral cervical segments.

Subsequent studies (e.g., Mehler et al., 60; Bowsher, 61; Mehler, 69; Boivie, 71, 791, using the more reliable silver impregnation degeneration techniques, as well as electrophysiological studies (e.g., Trevino et al., 72, 73; AlbeFessard et al., 74; Giesler et al., 76), have shown that this speculation went too far: there are certainly some fibres that project directly to the thalamus from the more caudal parts of the spinal cord.
Yet if these fibres represent only a small part of the projection ascending from the spinal cord, Rothmann s suggestion may be close to the truth.

The present findings demonstrate that it is so for the rat at least: apart from the DHvm system, very few neurons project to the thalamus from the lower part of the cord; much larger numbers do so from the highest cervical levels; and it is tempting to suggest that these high cervical cells represent relays for information ascending from the lower levels.

Although degeneration studies cannot give firm quantitative information, and there may well be some significant species differences, it has been repeatedly noted, by different workers and in a variety of species including man, that most of the fibres in the anterolateral funiculus appear to terminate in the reticular formation and in other regions of the brainstem, rather than in the thalamus: at least, when the funiculus is cut, most of the terminal degeneration is seen in those sites (e.g., Kuru, '49; Morin et al., '51; Anderson and Berry, '59; Mehler et al., '60; Mehler,'62; Kerr, '75b; Zemlan et al., '78).

It is well established (Purpura and Yahr, '66; Iggo, '73; Bonica, '74; and Bonica et al., '79, for reviews), and also clear from the present observations, that the thalamus in turn receives projections from many of these brainstem cell groups.

The present study shows that there is no obvious dividing line between the set of cell groups projecting to the thalamus from the brainstem and those projecting from the most rostral part of the spinal cord: they all appear to belong to a single archipelago.

Moreover, at least three of the groups of cells seen at high cervical levels in this study-the gracile, cuneate, and lateral cervical nuclei-are well known from previous work to be rostral relays for information ascending from caudal regions (Nathan and Smith, '59; and Willis and Coggeshall, '78, for reviews).
The experiments of Carstens and Trevino ('78b) on the VHd group in the cat suggest that the same may be true of it.

In general, there is very little evidence as to the functions of the other high cervical groups seen in this study, and little to contradict the suggestion that they follow the precedent set by the gracile, cuneate, and lateral cervical nuclei.

While there have been physiological investigations of cells in the appropriate Rexed laminae, such as those of Christensen and Per1 ('70) on the nociceptive cells of the marginal zone, these have mostly concentrated on more caudal regions of the spinal cord (Brown, '81; Willis and Coggeshall, '78, for review).

The one necessary qualification to the present suggestion that the high cervical groups are relays for much more caudal afferents concerns the trigeminal system: it may be that some of the cells seen in this study, especially in the groups M, SGv, and N, are relaying trigeminal input, but probably only to a very small extent if at all (Kerr, '70a,b); these three groups in any case represent only a small proportion of the total high cervical spinothalamic population detected here.

If it is true that the spinothalamic groups identified in this work receive input from neurons located more caudally in the spinal cord, then an obvious area of future study would be the anatomical identification of these lower links in the chain, i.e., the links between the primary afferents and the directly spinothalamic (or medullothalamic) fibres.

Such identification has already been made in the case of spinal input to dorsal column nuclei (which also receive primary afferent input) (e.g., Rustioni, '73, '74; Rustioni and Kaufman, '77; and for reviews, Nathan and Smith, '59; and Willis and Coggeshall, '78), and to the lateral cervical nucleus (e.g., Hongo et al., '68; Bryan et al., '73, '74; Jankowska, '75; Brown et al., '76; Craig, '76; Jankowska et al., '76 Snow et al., '76; Cervero et al., '77; Willis and Coggeshall, '78, for review; Giesler et al., '79b, in the rat).

But very little is known specifically as to the possible spinal input to the other cervical spinothalamic groups-especially those in the deeper laminae (the intermediate gray, IGZ, the ipsilaterally projecting dorsal area of the ventral horn, VHd, and the ventral extreme of the ventral horn, VHv).

Certainly the idea that there are polyneuronal (multisynaptic) routes by which sensory information ascends through the spinal cord toward the brainstem, and that propriospinal and spinobulbar systems are crucial to pain sensibility, is very old (e.g., May, '06; Karplus and Kreidl, '25; Nathan and Smith, '59; Noordenbos, '59; Poggio and Mountcastle, '60; Melzack and Wall, '65; Basbaum, '73; Kerr, '75a; Wall, '78; Bowsher '79; Cook et al., '84; Peschanski and Besson, '84; and or reviews, Bonica and AlbeFessard, '76; Willis and Coggeshall, '78).

More recently, the importance of reticular formation relays, including those in the lower medulla, in transmitting ascending sensory messages has been emphasized (Herrick and Bishop, '58; Nauta and Kuypers, '58; Albe-Fessard et al., '74a,b; Kerr, '75a,b; Nauta, '75; Kevetter and Willis, '82-'84; Levante et al., '83; Peschanski and Besson, '84; Menhtrey et al., '84a; Wiberg and Blomqvist, '84).

And Basbaum ('73) has demonstrated that a short fibre, polysynaptic, propriospinal system is capable of conveying nociceptive information rostrally in the absence of the long ascending systems (Basbaum, '73).

Thus while the more caudal parts of the spinal cord do contain cells that project directly to the thalamus, and this projection may well play some part in the perception of pain and temperature, its role may be small compared with that of the polysynaptic pathways.

Neither degeneration experiments nor electrophysiological studies, with their uncertainties of measurement, sampling, and localization, can decide quantitative questions about the relative importance of the different modes of ascent to the thalamus.

There are certainly species differences in the spinothalamic system (see, for example, Mehler '69); but it is entirely possible that other mammals may resemble rats at least to the extent that cells projecting to the thalamus from the more caudal regions of the spinal cord are few by comparison with those projecting from the uppermost cervical segments.
Relevance to man.

There is some remarkable clinical evidence, first reported by Hitchcock ('70, '74) and since confirmed by others (Papo and Luongo, '76; Nathan, '77; Schvarcz, '77, '78; Cook et al., '84), which cannot be explained by traditional views of the human spinothalamic tract, but for which the present findings suggest a straightforward interpretation.

The clinical observations have to do with the consequences of commissural myelotomy, an operation in which a lesion in the midline of the spinal cord is employed to interrupt pain pathways in patients suffering from intractable pain.

The rationale of the surgery is as follows: Pain, temperature, and crude touch primary efferents terminate in the cord at or close to their level of dorsal root entry; and second-order pain and temperature fibres, arising from cells in the dorsal horn, then cross the midline close to the segment in which their cell bodies lie, before ascending in the anterolateral funiculus.

Primary afferents for discriminative fine touch and proprioception, by contrast, ascend through the dorsal fasciculi without crossing the midline, to synapse with the gracile and cuneate nuclei in the medulla; and it is from there that second-order neurons cross the midline to ascend to the thalamus.

Thus, it is hoped, by interrupting only commissural fibres of the spinal levels corresponding to the painful body region, that one should selectively abolish the pain at those body levels without losing fine touch and proprioception (and without losing the ability to feel pain at other body levels both above and below the lesion).

This operation is an advance on the older technique of employing an anterolateral cordotomy (a transverse cut through all the anterolateral fibres at a particular cord level), which is necessarily more invasive and, predictably, results in loss of pain sensation at every level below and contralateral to the cordotomy, as well as interrupting all other pathways in the anterolateral funiculus.
Commissural myelotomies performed at most cord levels, like anterolateral cordotomies, result in sensory deficits largely in accord with expectations.

But in patients in which a commissural myelotomy is performed at the highest cervical levels or just at the medulldcord junction, sensory deficits are observed far lower in the trunk and periphery than predicted.

A C1 commissural myelotomy, even one so short as to extend less than a whole segment, may be observed to result in sensory deficits over virtually the entire body-sparing perhaps only a small muzzle area of the face (Nathan, 77, and personal communication; Cook et al., 84).

These findings cannot be explained by traditional concepts of the anatomy of the spinothalamic tract, and are at least consistent with a specialised rostra1 cord system of somatosensory nuclei that receive and relay sensory information to the thalamus from lower (mainly ipsilateral) levels of the neuraxis, as is proposed in the present study.
